Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Situation2: The polls close for good tonight, and this moment is the voter’s sole opportunity to present the mandated ID.
Story: My granddaughter sat across from me, her eyes wide with uncertainty as she asked, “Grandpa, how did you know what to do when you started college?” I could see she needed more than a quick answer—she needed the kind of guidance only time and patience could give. I wanted to share my stories, to help her find her footing, to be the steady hand she’s always counted on. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart pounded. The polls would close in less than an hour, and this was my only chance to vote. I still needed to find my ID, tucked away somewhere in the house. The weight of my civic duty pressed on me; I’d always told my family how important it was to have a voice in our democracy. Yet here was my granddaughter, looking to me for wisdom, and I felt torn in two. I wanted to be present for her, to offer the guidance she deserved, but the responsibility of voting tugged at me with equal force. My hands trembled as I tried to decide which role to honor in this fleeting moment.
